text: So I guess while I love mental models, while I love frameworks, what I want people who listen to me and maybe listen to you to understand is you have to go deeper. Because as situations change, as an investor and advisor to startups, I advise differently if you are just starting, if you're in the middle, and if you're scaling. In the book that I'm writing on product, I actually make that distinction a lot in the book, which stage are you?
speaker: Oji Udezue
context: Lenny asks Oji about his perspective on frameworks broadly after noting that Oji had an interesting response when asked about frameworks. Oji explains that while he appreciates frameworks and mental models as shortcuts for dense thinking, he believes product managers need to understand the fundamentals behind frameworks rather than applying them blindly. He emphasizes that product management isn't a science and involves significant uncertainty, so practitioners must adapt frameworks to their specific stage and situation.
text_ko: 사고 모델(mental models)도 좋아하고 프레임워크(frameworks)도 좋아하긴 한데, 제 얘기를 듣는 분들—그리고 아마 당신의 청중들도—에게 꼭 전하고 싶은 건 한 단계 더 깊이 들어가야 한다는 거예요. 상황이 바뀌면 접근도 달라지거든요. 저는 스타트업(startups)에 투자자이자 조언자로서, 막 시작하는 단계인지, 한창 진행 중인지, 확장 단계(scaling)인지에 따라 조언을 다르게 해요. 제가 지금 쓰고 있는 제품(product) 관련 책에서도 그걸 자주 구분해서 다루고 있어요 — 당신은 지금 어느 단계인가요?
text_zh: 所以虽然我很喜欢心智模型(mental models)，也很喜欢各种框架，但我希望听我们说话的人能明白一点——你得往深了挖。因为情况在变，作为投资人和创业顾问，我给刚起步的公司、发展中的公司，还有在扩张期的公司，建议都不一样。我正在写的这本产品书里，其实经常会提到这个区别——你现在处在哪个阶段？
text_es: Mira, aunque me encantan los modelos mentales, aunque me encantan los frameworks, lo que quiero que entienda la gente que me escucha y que tal vez te escucha a ti es que tienen que profundizar más. Porque conforme van cambiando las situaciones, como inversionista y asesor de startups, yo asesoro de manera diferente si apenas estás empezando, si estás en la mitad del proceso, o si ya estás escalando. En el libro que estoy escribiendo sobre producto, de hecho hago mucho esa distinción en el libro: ¿en qué etapa te encuentras?
key_sentence: You have to go deeper; situations change at different stages.

text: Frequent is every day really or multiple times a week. Infrequent starts to be like two times a week, once a month. And of course there's a big interregnum in the middle of that.
speaker: Oji Udezue
context: Lenny asks Oji to clarify what constitutes 'frequent' in his framework for finding big B2B SaaS opportunities. Oji had previously explained his framework that segments workflows by how many departments they affect (everyone vs niche) and how frequently they're executed. This response defines the frequency dimension of his framework, explaining that truly frequent workflows happen daily or multiple times per week, while infrequent ones might be twice weekly or monthly.
text_ko: 빈번하다는 건 보통 매일이거나 주에 여러 번을 말해요. 드문 편은 주에 두 번 정도나 한 달에 한 번쯤부터예요. 그리고 그 중간에는 큰 공백기(interregnum)가 있죠.
text_zh: 高频用户其实就是每天都用，或者一周用好几次的。低频用户呢，大概是一周用两次，或者一个月用一次这样。当然了，中间还有很大一块空白地带。
text_es: Frecuente significa realmente todos los días o varias veces por semana. Lo poco frecuente ya empieza a ser como dos veces por semana, una vez al mes. Y claro, hay un gran vacío en el medio de todo eso.
key_sentence: There's a big interregnum between infrequent and frequent.

text: The sharp problem is a little bit of that whole quadrant framework, which is what problem are you going to work on? I think that problems have predictive power of success if you actually solve the problem. And this is different from, I have an idea, yeah. I think that a lot of innovation can come from inspiration, but the best inspiration comes from understanding customers and their problems.
speaker: Oji Udezue
context: Lenny asks Oji about his concept of starting with a 'sharp problem' in PLG product development. Oji explains that focusing on sharp problems - those that materially steal customers' time, energy, money, or focus - has predictive power for startup success. He distinguishes between having an idea versus identifying a genuinely painful problem that customers desperately want solved, emphasizing that the best innovation comes from deep customer problem understanding rather than just inspiration.
text_ko: 핵심 문제는 그 사분면 프레임워크(quadrant framework)에서 ‘어떤 문제를 다룰 것인가’를 정하는 한 부분이에요. 제가 보기엔, 문제를 실제로 해결하면 그 문제 자체가 성공 가능성을 예측해주는 힘이 있어요. 단순히 ‘아이디어가 있다’는 것과는 다른 얘기죠. 영감에서 많은 혁신(innovation)이 나오긴 하지만, 최고의 영감은 고객과 그들의 문제를 이해할 때 온다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 关键问题其实就是那个四象限框架(quadrant framework)的一部分，就是你要解决什么问题？我觉得如果你真的能解决这个问题，那这个问题本身就能预测你会不会成功。这跟"我有个想法"是完全不一样的。我认为很多创新都可以从灵感中来，但最好的灵感其实是来自于对客户和他们痛点的深度理解。
text_es: El tema clave está en ese marco de cuadrantes, ¿no? O sea, ¿en qué problema te vas a enfocar realmente? Yo creo que los problemas tienen un poder predictivo del éxito si de verdad logras resolverlos. Y esto es muy diferente a decir "se me ocurrió una idea", ¿me entiendes? Pienso que mucha innovación puede venir de la inspiración, pero la mejor inspiración surge cuando realmente entiendes a tus clientes y sus problemas.
key_sentence: Problems have predictive power of success when solved.

text: When you see people's eyes get big and they expose more whites to you, you're probably onto something. It's not enough, that's not a workflow thing, that's an excitement thing. But people often react that way when you're solving a really sharp problem for them. And then people spontaneously bring up money, it's like when can I pay?
speaker: Oji Udezue
context: Lenny asks Oji about signs that indicate you've identified a sharp enough problem for your product. Oji explains his 'whites of their eyes' concept - when you present a problem to potential customers and see their eyes widen with excitement, exposing more of the whites of their eyes. He describes this physical reaction as a strong indicator that you're addressing a genuinely painful problem, especially when customers spontaneously start discussing payment or urgency around getting access to your solution.
text_ko: 사람들 눈이 커지고 흰자가 더 보일 정도면, 뭔가 제대로 건드린 거예요. 그 자체만으로는 충분하진 않아요 — 워크플로(workflow) 문제가 아니라 사람들의 흥분의 문제죠. 보통 정말 핵심적인 문제를 해결해줄 때 사람들이 그렇게 반응해요. 그러다 보면 사람들이 스스로 돈 얘기를 꺼내요. “언제 결제하면 되죠?” 이런 식으로요.
text_zh: 当你看到别人眼睛瞪得老大，露出更多眼白的时候，说明你可能找对路子了。光这样还不够，这不是什么工作流程的问题，这是兴奋劲儿上来了。但是当你真正帮他们解决了一个很棘手的问题时，人们经常会有这种反应。然后他们就会主动提到钱的事儿，就像"我什么时候能付钱？"
text_es: Cuando veas que a la gente se le abren los ojos como platos y se quedan así, probablemente has dado en el clavo. No es suficiente, eso no es cosa del proceso de trabajo, es pura emoción. Pero la gente suele reaccionar así cuando les estás resolviendo un problema que realmente les duele. Y entonces empiezan a sacar el tema del dinero por sí solos, te dicen "¿cuándo puedo pagarte?"
key_sentence: You're probably onto something when you see the whites of their eyes.

text: One of the big, hairy, audacious goals of product management is being able to process these signals efficiently. We did it in a certain way at Calendly, which I drew a rig together through workflows and Slack, and then having individuals triage those things.
speaker: Oji Udezue
context: Oji is explaining his concept of 'customer listening' - systematically processing customer signals that happen naturally through social media, app stores, support tickets, NPS surveys, and sales data. He distinguishes this from customer discovery, describing it as capturing feedback that customers are already providing whether you're listening or not. He explains that efficiently processing these signals is a major challenge in product management, requiring systematic workflows to triage and act on customer feedback.
text_ko: 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)에서 거대하고 대담한 목표 중 하나는 이런 신호(signals)를 효율적으로 처리할 수 있게 되는 거예요. 캘린들리(Calendly)에선 제가 워크플로(workflows)와 슬랙(Slack)을 엮어 하나의 구성(rig)을 만들고, 사람들이 그 항목들을 트리아지(triage)하도록 했어요.
text_zh: 产品管理的一个超级大胆的目标就是能够高效地处理这些信号。我们在Calendly是这么做的，我把工作流程和Slack整合在一起搭了个系统，然后让团队成员去分类处理这些事情。
text_es: Uno de los objetivos más ambiciosos y desafiantes del product management es poder procesar estas señales de manera eficiente. En Calendly lo hicimos de una forma particular - armé un sistema combinando workflows y Slack, y luego tuvimos gente encargada de priorizar y clasificar todo eso.
key_sentence: Big, hairy, audacious goals involve efficiently processing signals.

text: Virality is really when the word of mouth of a product is high quality. That's really the essence of it. Let me rephrase that. It's when customers market your product. And that is incredibly powerful, but also that's incredibly actionable, if that makes sense.
speaker: Oji Udezue
context: Lenny asks Oji about tactics for increasing product virality, especially for B2B products. Oji starts by redefining virality, explaining that many people misunderstand it as synthetic tactics like referral programs. He defines true virality as high-quality word of mouth where customers naturally market your product for you. He emphasizes this definition is actionable because it focuses on building something customers genuinely want to share rather than relying on artificial viral mechanisms.
text_ko: 바이럴성(virality)은 제품에 대한 입소문이 질적으로 뛰어날 때예요. 그게 바로 핵심이에요. 다시 말하면 고객들이 스스로 제품을 마케팅해 줄 때라는 뜻이에요. 그건 굉장히 강력하고, 동시에 실행 가능한 것이기도 해요, 이해되시죠?
text_zh: 病毒式传播(virality)其实就是产品的口碑特别好。这就是核心所在。让我换个说法吧。就是客户主动帮你推广产品。这个力量非常强大，关键是也很好操作，你明白我的意思吧。
text_es: La viralidad es básicamente cuando el boca a boca de un producto es de muy buena calidad. Esa es la esencia del asunto. Déjame decirlo de otra manera. Es cuando tus propios clientes se encargan de promocionar tu producto. Y eso es súper poderoso, pero también es algo muy concreto en lo que puedes trabajar, ¿me explico?
key_sentence: Virality is when customers market your product; it's incredibly actionable.

text: Forest time is the idea that you make time within your week, within your month to see the forest for the trees. Most of the time when you're operating, you're seeing the tree, which is the problem in front of you. But sometimes you need to see the forest, so you can figure out it as an alternate path, different from the one that you are currently on your campaign.
speaker: Oji Udezue
context: Lenny asks Oji to explain his concept of 'forest time' that he wrote about in a post. Oji explains that when you're operating day-to-day in a company, you get caught up in immediate problems (seeing the trees) and lose the bigger picture perspective (seeing the forest). Forest time is intentionally scheduled time - like a day per month - to step back and gain a bird's eye view of your situation, identify alternative paths, and improve your strategic aim before executing further.
vocabulary_highlights: see the forest for the trees
text_ko: 숲을 보는 시간(forest time)은 일주일이나 한 달 단위로 잠깐 시간을 내 전체를 바라보는 시간을 만드는 아이디어예요. 보통 운영할 때는 눈앞의 문제, 즉 한 그루의 나무만 보게 되지만, 가끔은 숲 전체를 봐야 지금 진행 중인 캠페인(campaign)과는 다른 대안 경로를 찾아낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 森林时间(Forest time)就是说，你要在每周或每月专门抽出时间来看大局。平时我们忙起来的时候，眼里只有眼前这棵树，也就是手头的问题。但有时候你得跳出来看整片森林，这样才能发现别的路子，而不是一直埋头走现在这条路。
text_es: El "tiempo de bosque" (forest time) es la idea de que te reserves tiempo durante la semana, durante el mes, para ver el panorama completo. La mayoría del tiempo cuando estás operando, solo ves el árbol, que es el problema que tienes enfrente. Pero a veces necesitas ver todo el bosque para darte cuenta de que hay un camino alternativo, diferente al que estás siguiendo actualmente en tu campaña.
key_sentence: See the forest for the trees to find an alternate path on your campaign.
